did.unittitle: Union League of Philadelphia Civil War collection

bioghist.p: The Union League of Philadelphia was founded in 1862 as a patriotic society to support the policies of President Abraham Lincoln. It evolved to its current identity as a non-sectarian and non-partisan private club. In 1962 the Union League decided it would form a collection of Civil War materials and published its intention. At least one acquisition was made as a result of this effort.

scopecontent.p: The series has been arranged into three subseries: Union League Military, Other Military, and Ephemera. Union League Military materials include: Col. Harmanus papers related to the 196th Regiment Pennsylvania, 5th Union League, including letters, ordnance receipts, reports and muster rolls; Lt. Col. Jacob M. Davis papers related to the 213th Regiment Pennsylvania, 7th Union League, including special and general orders, correspondence relating primarily to furlough requests, Company returns and tri-monthly reports, and Court Martial case reports including charges (mostly Absent Without Leave), specifications, findings, and sentences, as well as Reports of the Guard; an Adjutant General's Office Clothing Book for the 183rd Regiment Pennsylvania, 4th Union League, Cos. A, B, C, D; and miscellaneous muster rolls and bounties for 1st, 2nd, and 3rd Union League Regiments. Other Civil War papers include: soldier's letters to Hannah Eliza Delp from cousins and friends; David S. Hall Morgan letters; John Martin Steffan letters; Robert M. Green record books, clippings, transcripts and other material relating to the history of the 124th Pennsylvania Regiment, with invitations, programs, George Gordon Meade Post GAR, 1862-1911; William Thomas Jones letters; record book of relief work for Civil War Veterans and their families; and miscellaneous discharges, letters, and a scrapbook.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.
